We investigate the interaction dynamics between TiCl4 molecules and a MgCl2 (110) cluster to understand the complexities of Ziegler-Natta catalysts through molecular dynamics simulations. Our study reveals significant distortion of Mg atoms at the edge of cluster, influencing TiCl4 adsorption behavior, cluster stability, and reactivity. Various TiCl4 configurations on the MgCl2 surface, such as octahedral and bridging forms, illustrate the versatility of surface in accommodating different molecular arrangements, affecting catalytic performance. We explore diverse adsorption sites influenced by surface topology and electronic properties, revealing a range of adsorption energies from 15.7 to 29.2 kcal/mol. This indicates a complex interplay of molecular forces, significantly impacting catalytic efficiency at distorted sites. Nudged Elastic Band calculations reveal varied activation energies for ethylene insertion, suggesting faster reaction rates at certain sites and highlighting highly favorable dynamics at Corradini type Ti active sites. All these findings offer new directions for enhancing catalyst performances. These catalysts are renowned for their efficiency in polymerizing olefins, yet a comprehensive understanding of the titanium active site structures within these catalysts remains elusive [1]. This gap in knowledge challenges the optimization of catalyst performance and enhancement of the resulting polyolefin properties. This study revisits and sheds light on the configurations of these titanium active sites, which are essential in determining the efficiency of heterogeneous ZN catalyst system. The quest to unravel the complexities of ZN catalysts has increasingly leveraged computational techniques, reflecting a concerted effort to bridge the gap between theoretical models and the multifaceted reality of catalytic processes. The work of Cavallo and colleagues stands as a cornerstone in this domain, which offered an extensive review of how computational methods have shed light on various facets of ZN systems [2]. Despite the insights garnered from these studies, traditional computational models often portray oversimplified versions of ZN catalysts, which fall short of capturing the full spectrum of intricacies encountered under actual operational conditions. Recognizing this gap, our research attempted to address these limitations by providing a more nuanced and accurate depiction of the titanium active sites in ZN catalysts. In doing so, we build upon the previous foundational works, whose contributions have been instrumental in advancing our understanding of ZN catalysts. The studies, ranging from the crystal structure of MgCl2 supports and characterization of active sites with TiCl4, to the impacts of internal and external donors, offered a rich tapestry of knowledge that our work seeks to complement. In particular, the computational exploration of binding structures on MgCl2 surfaces, stereospecific control mechanisms, and the alkylation process of TiCl4 by triethylaluminum (TEA) as a cocatalyst can also considerably affect the catalytic behavior [3], among other aspects, laying a robust foundation for further investigation. Noteworthy among these contributions is the ab initio molecular dynamics (MD) study by Boero [4], which has significantly influenced the computational approach to ZN catalysts, demonstrating the potential of these methodologies to elucidate complex chemical phenomena. Moreover, the extensive reviews by Cavallo [2] and Gupta [5], alongside the impactful works of Busico [6], Taniike [7], Ziegler and their colleagues [8], have collectively provided a comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art in computational modeling of heterogeneous ZN catalysts. These contributions underscore the deep and broad impact of computational studies on our understanding of ZN catalyst systems. By integrating these insights, our research focus is not only to bridge the existing gaps but also to propel the field towards more accurate and predictive models that reflect the true complexity of ZN catalysts. The primary objectives of this research are to refine our understanding of the active center structures for the titanium site in ZN catalysts, with a focus on ethylene polymerization. We aim to conduct a detailed investigation of these diverse titanium active sites within ZN catalyst systems [9–11] to understand their structural characteristics and influence on the ethylene polymerization process. Furthermore, this study seeks to bridge the theoretical and practical aspects of catalyst modeling by addressing discrepancies arising from oversimplified computational models. By employing advanced computational modeling techniques, such as Universal Neural Network Potentials (UNNPs [12–16]), which could be explored as a promising approach to approximate the results of Density Functional Theory (DFT) methods while managing computational demands effectively, this study aims to offer a balance between accuracy and computational efficiency. This approach will enable a detailed and accurate representation of the titanium active sites, providing insights closer to the actual behavior of these catalysts in industrial settings. By providing a more accurate and detailed depiction of the titanium active sites, this research could lead to the development of catalysts with improved efficiency and specificity. Such advancements could have far-reaching implications to produce polyethylene, potentially leading to improved material properties and more sustainable manufacturing processes. 2 Computational methods We applied the PreFerred Potential (PFP) model version 4.0.0 as a Universal Neural Network Potential (UNNP) estimator for the computation of atomic forces and partial charges. The model architecture of PFP is founded on the tensor embedded atom network (TeaNet), a Neural Network Potential (NNP) based on graph convolutional networks (GCN) [17,18]. This architecture ensures high accuracy across multi-element systems and is especially applicable to heterogenous catalyst structures. To ensure the reliability of our computational approach, we have taken appropriate measures to validate the UNNPs for their specific system. In a separate publication [19], we have conducted an intensive checking of the validity of the UNNP method for the Ziegler-Natta catalyst system. This separate publication details the validation procedures, benchmark calculations, and comparisons with experimental data or higher-level theoretical methods. By dedicating an entire study to validating the UNNP approach, we have demonstrated our commitment to ensuring the accuracy and reliability of our simulations. All calculations in this work are performed using the Matlantis software [20], which is integrated with the PFP model through its API (Application Programming Interface) client, version 1.11.0. Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE [21]) library serves as our computational platform, operating in 'CRYSTAL_PLUS_D3′ mode to include DFT-D3 dispersion corrections with 3-D periodicity. This mode is an enhanced feature of the PFP model that incorporates DFT-D3 dispersion corrections [22,23]. These corrections enable the model to capture dispersion forces that were not included in its original DFT-based training data [23]. The geometries of the models were optimized using the BFGS (Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno) method in ASE, with a maximum force threshold (fmax_threshold) set at 0.005. Our research primarily utilized the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) [24] method to investigate the activation energy barriers associated with ethylene insertion reactions, facilitated by Ziegler-Natta catalysts [19]. The NEB algorithm comprises a string of 21 images (Replica 0–20), representing the reactants, transition states, and products, connected by an elastic band with a spring constant of 0.05, a step of 20,000 steps and a maximum force (fmax) set to 0.01. The Fast Inertial Relaxation Engine (FIRE) algorithm [25] was employed for NEB optimization, proving particularly effective for the complex systems under study. The widely recognized mechanism for olefin insertion into the titanium-carbon (Ti-C) bond, originally proposed by Arlman and Cossee [26], starts with the formation of a π-complex as the olefin coordinates to the metal atom. During the propagation phase, the olefin inserts into the Ti-C bond, resulting in a four-center transition state (TS). This transition state leads to the formation of a new intermediate, where the alkyl chain includes the newly inserted olefin. Molecular Dynamic Simulations were performed with an NVT ensemble at a given temperature and at 1 atmospheric pressure for 1 picosecond (dt = 0.1 fs) without any fixing of the positions of atoms. The reason for selecting these simulation conditions is to mimic the reaction conditions during the catalyst preparation process, where excess TiCl4 molecules interact with the MgCl2 support. The chosen temperature of 343 K (approximately 70 °C, at atmospheric pressure) is typical for this step in the catalyst preparation process, as described in the cited reference [27]. By conducting simulations at this specific temperature and under constant volume and temperature conditions (NVT ensemble), we aim to replicate the realistic scenario where the MgCl2 support is suspended in excess TiCl4 solution during the catalyst preparation stage. This approach ensures that our simulations closely reflect the actual experimental conditions, providing more accurate and relevant insights into the behavior and interactions of the components involved in the catalyst preparation process. The modeling and pictorial outputs were generated using Avogadro 1.2.0 [28] and Jmol 16.1.27 [29], respectively. 2.1 Preparation of a large cluster model for a MgCl2 (110) surface 2.1.1 Base cluster model preparation The initial phase of our experiment involved constructing a slab to accurately emulate the β-MgCl2 (100) surface. In the Ziegler-Natta catalyst academic and industrial community, it is widely recognized that the surface of MgCl2 (110) is the primary location for the titanium active site for isospecific polymerization, among other possible locations on the MgCl2 surface, such as (104). While the α-polymorph of MgCl2 is frequently employed as the base model in simulations, it is crucial to recognize that Ziegler-Natta catalysts typically comprise a mixture of both α and β polymorphs of MgCl2. As reported in previous work, the ratio of α to β polymorphs can range from 0.329 to 2.0 [30,31] The decision to utilize the β-form was motivated by its simpler stacking arrangement, following an ABAB… pattern, which renders it more conducive for elucidating the interactions of active sites on neighboring layers. This contrasts with the more intricate ABCABC… stacking exhibited by the α-form. This simpler arrangement of the β-polymorph allows for a clearer investigation of the interactions and behaviors of the active sites during the catalyst preparation process. This foundational model is critical as it serves as the cornerstone for all subsequent computational modeling. Our approach involved assembling a three-layer slab, integrating six magnesium layers to authentically reflect the surface properties of MgCl2. In our previous work, we reported the validity of such slab model [19]. The slab, comprising 81 MgCl2 units ((MgCl2)81), was carefully calibrated to offer a detailed representation of surface interactions, while also being mindful of computational constraints. The dimensions, approximately 28 Å x 15 Å x 23 Å, were meticulously chosen to ensure a harmonious balance between a sufficiently large surface area for accurate representation [32–36] and the limitations imposed by computational resources. Fig. 1 provides a detailed visual representation of this base cluster model, highlighting its intricate structure and carefully calculated dimensions. 2.1.2 PBC cell box model construction Building upon the base cluster model, the next critical step involved encapsulating this model within a larger periodic boundary condition (PBC) cell box, measuring 50 Å x 50 Å x 50 Å. This step is pivotal in our simulation process, as it allows us to mimic the infinite expanse of a catalyst particle model within a finite computational framework. The strategic central placement of the base cluster model within the PBC cell is a nuanced decision, ensuring an even distribution of space around the model. This uniformity is essential for an accurate simulation of surface interactions, as it minimizes potential distortions arising from edge effects. The dimensions of the PBC cell box were selected after thorough consideration, balancing the need to provide ample space around the base cluster model while preventing any spurious interactions between the replicated images of the model, which could lead to erroneous results. 2.1.3 Preparation of the catalyst model The construction of our catalyst model began with strategically positioning (TiCl4)n molecules around the MgCl2 (110) cluster model. This precise arrangement is essential to our research, as it accurately represents the catalytic interface, a key focus of our study. To simulate a pseudo liquid-phase environment, we surrounded the cluster with 100 TiCl4 molecules, creating a surplus of TiCl4 relative to MgCl2. This setup mimics the typical conditions found in ZN catalyst preparation.1 We achieved this distribution using a specially designed Python script, which ensured a random yet even spread of TiCl4 molecules around the MgCl2 cluster. The script's algorithm was carefully adjusted to mirror liquid-phase conditions, providing a more lifelike simulation environment. Fig. 2 displays this initial arrangement, showing the spatial distribution of TiCl4 molecules before starting the molecular dynamics simulation. The molecular dynamics (MD) simulation was carried out under NVT conditions (constant number of particles, volume, and temperature), maintaining the system at 343 K. The simulation lasted for 1 picosecond, a duration selected to observe the dynamic interactions between the TiCl4 molecules and the MgCl2 surface. This phase is vital as it allows us to study the behavior and positioning of the TiCl4 molecules in relation to the MgCl2 surface under controlled conditions. Post-simulation, we closely examined the coordination of TiCl4 molecules on the MgCl2 surface, identifying and confirming their connected points. Our findings showed that 6 TiCl4 molecules successfully coordinated with the MgCl2 base cluster model. Subsequently, we removed any unreacted or loosely bound TiCl4 molecules from the PBC cell box, noting that the cluster model was slightly tilted during the MD calculations (refer to Fig. 2). This step was crucial for maintaining the integrity and accuracy of model. The final stage involved optimizing the structure, a critical process that fine-tunes the positions of atoms and molecules in our model, resulting in a stable and realistic catalyst representation. The optimization was conducted as described in the Computational Method section. The optimized model, now consisting of 81 MgCl2 and 6 TiCl4 molecules, is shown in Fig. 3 . In our model, the TiCl4 molecules exhibit three distinct structural forms: four molecules in an octahedral configuration (like the Corradini type model [1,2], C-1, C-2, C-3, and C-4), one in a bridge type [2,4] (B), and another at the edge of the MgCl2 cluster [7] (E). Each form, with their unique features and implications, is illustrated in Fig. 4 . Table 1 lists critical parameters for these configurations, including the distances between Ti and Cla, Ti and Clb, the Cla-Ti-Clb angle, and the Ti atom charges. Cla and Clb denote the terminal chlorine atoms not involved in a binding structure. The charges on the titanium atoms in the C-1 to C-4 structures are similar, indicating little electrical variation, though differences in distortion are noted. In contrast, the charge of titanium in the Bridge (B) and Edge (E) structures is lower than that in the C-type configurations. These structural variations, which align with previous research findings [19,36–42], emerged naturally through our MD simulations, without manual construction. These depictions provide a detailed view of the varied coordination modes of TiCl4 on the MgCl2 surface, offering vital insights into the structural dynamics at play. 2.2 Preparation of reactant and product models for neb calculations Our NEB (Nudged Elastic Band) calculations commenced with the utilization of the cluster model described in previous sections, essential for representing the Ti (III)-Et complex. A key step in our methodology involved modifying the TiCl4 molecule by replacing terminal chlorine atoms. Specifically, we substituted two chlorine atoms at the targeted active Ti site with an ethyl group and an ethylene molecule. This modification is integral to our approach, aiming to replicate the chemical environment and reaction dynamics typical in real-world Ziegler-Natta catalyst. For the other five Ti sites in the models, we replaced one chlorine atom with an ethyl group and removed the other chlorine atoms that were not binding with Mg atoms. This substitution strategy is crucial as it mirrors the electron configuration and reactivity characteristics of Ti (III) species, commonly observed in polymerization processes involving Ziegler-Natta catalysts and co-catalysts like triethylaluminum (TEA). In such systems, TEA serves a dual function, both as an alkylating agent and as a reducing agent for the active titanium site. This alteration transforms the remaining TiCl4 molecules in our cluster into TiCl2(Et) configurations, ensuring our model accurately represents the electronic environment of Ti (III) species in actual catalytic systems [1]. The orientation of ethylene molecule was adjusted to a vertical position to an alkyl chain, based on empirical data and theoretical studies [4,19]. This orientation is considered crucial for the ethylene insertion process into the Ti-Cl bond. Fig. 5 visually represents the Reactant and Product models for the C-1 site, respectively. The ethylene insertion reaction into Ti-Et group is assumed to proceed the Arlman-Cossee mechanism [26]. These models provide a clear depiction of the molecular arrangements before and after the reaction, serving as a visual aid to enhance our theoretical analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Exploring surface interaction dynamics Our comprehensive analysis of the MgCl2 (110) cluster model, encompassing 81 MgCl2 units across three layers, delves into the intricate structural aspects of catalyst surfaces. The specific dimensions (28 Å x 15 Å x 23 Å) of the model are intentionally selected to mimic the typical size of catalysts in experimental studies [43], providing a solid foundation to examine the surface interactions in detail. A key finding from our study is the pronounced distortion of Mg atoms at the layer edges. This distortion is likely stemmed from complex interlayer binding dynamics, which could significantly modify the topology of surface and influence both the stability and reactivity of the cluster. These changes in surface structure are crucial as they likely affect the adsorption behavior of TiCl4 molecules. This points to a complex relationship between the structural properties of cluster and its catalytic performance. 3.2 Molecular dynamics simulation insights Utilizing dynamic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, our study diverges from traditional static methodologies, enabling real-time observation of TiCl4 molecules spontaneously adsorbing onto the MgCl2 surface. The resulting configurations of these molecules are diverse, including octahedral (6-fold Corradini type; C-1, C-2, C-3 and C-4), bridging (5-fold Bridge type; B), and penta-coordinated at the edge (5-fold Edge type; E) structures. This variety not only corroborates findings from prior research but also highlights the adaptability of the MgCl2 surface in accommodating multiple TiCl4 structural forms. The dynamic nature of these interactions, influenced by factors such as the surface topology of the MgCl2 cluster and the electronic properties of the TiCl4 molecules, is a critical aspect that emerged from our simulations. This complexity requires a deeper investigation into the interaction dynamics between TiCl4 molecules and the MgCl2 cluster. 3.3 Detailed analysis of adsorption energies The study of TiCl4 molecules adsorbed on the MgCl2 (110) cluster model revealed a wide range of adsorption energies, varying from 15.7 to 29.2 kcal/mol. The highest reliable value related to a 6-fold TiCl4 model was reported by D'Amore et al., who employed a periodic DFT method with dispersion correction techniques, yielding an energy of 28.6 kcal/mol [43]. Additionally, the adsorption energy for a TiCl4 molecule in an octahedral (6-fold) configuration, as described by Corradini's model, on a larger MgCl2 (110) surface slab model is found to be 29.3 kcal/mol [19]. This particular adsorbed structure closely resembles the C-1 type mentioned in this study (refer to Table 2 ). This range in adsorption energies suggests a complex array of molecular interactions at play, with each TiCl4 molecule engaging distinctively with the MgCl2 surface. It is important to note that the 5-fold Bridge (B) and Edge (E) configurations of TiCl4 are marked by lower adsorption energies compared to others. These configurations indicate a less robust but potentially more flexible interaction with the MgCl2 surface. This characteristic could lead to greater mobility or increased reactivity of the molecules, potentially resulting in more active catalytic sites under specific reaction conditions. 3.4 Addressing the influence of surface distortion Surface distortion plays a significant role in determining adsorption energies. In the MgCl2 (110) cluster model, a notable distortion is observed in the arrangement of Mg atoms, especially at the edges. This distortion creates non-uniform adsorption sites on the cluster surface or edges, which differ markedly from the more structured areas of the surface. These distinctive sites provide varied binding strengths and geometries for TiCl4 molecules, which could be a key factor in the range of adsorption energies observed. 3.5 Activation energy in catalysis: insights from neb calculations on ethylene insertion Our research, employing Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) calculations, has uncovered a wide spectrum of activation energies for the ethylene insertion reactions facilitated by TiCl4 on a MgCl2 surface. The energy barrier for an olefine insertion ranges approximately between 6 and 15 kcal/mol [19,44–47]. As is well known, these activation energies are pivotal in determining the likelihood of these reactions. We observed notable variations in these energies across different configurations of TiCl4. Specifically, models representing the Bridge (B) and Edge (E) types of TiCl4 sites exhibited lower activation energies compared to the conventional Corradini model (C-1) (Fig. 7). This suggests that reactions at the B and E sites might proceed more rapidly as compared to the reaction at the C-1 model. This hypothesis is further reinforced by the lower adsorption energies at these sites, implying that although the bonds formed with the surface might be weaker, the reactivity at these sites could be higher. This could be due to either increased molecular mobility or improved accessibility for the reactants at these sites. Interestingly, among the configurations we examined, the Corradini type site C-3 exhibited the lowest activation energy for ethylene insertion. This is noteworthy considering its structural resemblance to other Corradini types such as C-1, C-2, and C-4. However, unique placement of C-3 sets it apart; it is positioned diagonally inter-layer between the Bridge (B) and Edge (E) types, a layout depicted in Fig. 6 . In related research, Taniike and colleagues identified three distinct types of mononuclear 6-fold TiCl4 species on the same MgCl2 layer model [7]. Their classification, based on a three-site model [48], differs from ours, particularly in the environmental context surrounding TiCl4. This is like our prior findings, where a Ti active site is strategically located between two external donor molecules, demonstrated a reduction in activation energy for isotactic propylene insertion [19]. The active site at C-2 did not successfully complete a NEB calculation because the ethyl group detached from the titanium atom during the calculation process. Consequently, the titanium active site achieved stabilization through coordination with an ethylene molecule. Additionally, the positioning of C-2 at the edge contributes to its instability, rendering it less favorable for an ethylene insertion reaction. The variation in activation energy profoundly influences the behavior of Ziegler-Natta catalysts in olefin insertion reactions. According to the Arrhenius equation, the rate of a chemical reaction is exponentially related to the activation energy, meaning lower activation energies typically lead to higher reaction rates [49,50]. Therefore, active sites on a catalyst with lower activation energies are likely to facilitate faster olefin insertion reactions, contributing to higher overall polymerization rates. In addition to affecting reaction rates, these variations in activation energy can lead to differences in catalyst efficiency. Sites with lower activation energies tend to be more efficient in catalyzing the polymerization process, thereby enhancing the overall productivity of the catalyst. Furthermore, the activation energy can significantly influence the properties of the resulting polymer. Active sites with different activation energies can lead to polymers with varying chain lengths and molecular weights, resulting in a wide molecular weight distribution (MWD) that affects the mechanical and physical properties of polymer [50]. From an industrial perspective, lower activation energies are desirable as they can reduce the energy required for the polymerization process, making it more sustainable and cost-effective. In summary, understanding and controlling the variations in activation energy is key to optimizing catalyst design and polymer production, as these differences significantly impact the reaction rate, catalyst efficiency, properties of the resulting polymer, temperature sensitivity of the reaction, catalyst selectivity, and overall sustainability of the polymerization process. 3.6 Streamlining insights of Ziegler-Natta catalyst design for polymerization This research underlines the importance of designing catalysts to influence polymer traits based on activation energies. Our approach shows that understanding the link between catalytic activity and polymer traits allows the fine-tuning catalyst and enable the selective polymer production. For example, we found that the active site model (C-2) was ineffective, wasting titanium resources. This highlights the need to avoid or prevent such inefficient site production, suggesting further simulations to control titanium site distribution. This strategy aims to improve polymer yield and quality for industrial use and innovate production for specific applications. Our detailed analysis, with added data, highlights our implications of findings for Ziegler-Natta and other polymerization technologies, paving the way for new materials. Furthermore, our work reveals the complex nature of active sites in Ziegler-Natta catalysts, marked by varied adsorption and activation energies. This diversity suggests multiple polymerization pathways, affecting polymer molecular weight distributions. Distorted Mg atoms at cluster edges create unique active sites, potentially offering new polymerization routes. Understanding the impact of surface distortion on activity is key to catalyst optimization. Recognizing the importance of both high and low energy sites challenges traditional design approaches. By optimizing catalyst surfaces, we can better control polymerization, producing polymers with specific properties. 4 Conclusion This investigation into the MgCl2 (110) cluster model and its interaction with TiCl4 molecules has made significant contributions to the field of Ziegler-Natta catalysts. By studying a model comprising 81 MgCl2 units across three layers, which mirrors real catalysts in size and structure, we gained valuable insights into the effects of surface topology on catalytic behavior. The structural distortion of Mg atoms, particularly at layer edges, was found to influence the stability and reactivity of the cluster, impacting the adsorption behavior of TiCl4 molecules. Through dynamic molecular dynamics simulations, a variety of TiCl4 molecular configurations on the MgCl2 surface were observed. These configurations demonstrate the adaptability of surface in hosting different molecular arrangements, each with distinct catalytic implications. The study explored the complex dynamics of TiCl4 −MgCl2 interactions, revealing how differential adsorption at various sites is influenced by surface topology and electronic properties. The distorted Mg atoms at the cluster edges, for instance, create unique electronic environments, leading to varied adsorption strengths and reactivities. The range of adsorption energies observed, from 15.7 to 29.2 kcal/mol, underscores the complexity of molecular interactions and their implications for catalytic activity. NEB calculations further revealed diverse activation energies for ethylene insertion reactions, suggesting different reaction propensities across TiCl4 configurations. Notably, Bridge and Edge type models, despite weaker surface bonding, showed lower activation energies, indicating potential areas for enhanced reaction rates. Corradini type active sites, especially those between Bridge and Edge types, demonstrated the lowest activation energies, indicating highly favorable reaction dynamics in these specific locations. These findings challenge conventional catalyst design perspectives, especially in Ziegler-Natta catalysts, and open new avenues for developing more efficient and selective catalysts. Understanding the link among surface characteristics, adsorption as well as activation energies allows for the tailoring of catalysts for specific polymerization reactions, which could lead to polymers with desirable properties. Exploring the complex interactions in Ziegler-Natta catalysts remains unclear which need to be investigated deeply. Advanced computational and experimental methods are needed to map catalyst surface topology and link specific active sites to polymerization kinetics and the properties of resultant polymers. In conclusion, this study marks a pivotal step in comprehending Ziegler-Natta catalysts, offering insights that could significantly influence catalyst design and pave the way for more efficient, selective polymer production. coredata.dc:description: We investigate the interaction dynamics between TiCl4 molecules and a MgCl2 (110) cluster to understand the complexities of Ziegler-Natta catalysts through molecular dynamics simulations. Our study reveals significant distortion of Mg atoms at the edge of cluster, influencing TiCl4 adsorption behavior, cluster stability, and reactivity. Various TiCl4 configurations on the MgCl2 surface, such as octahedral and bridging forms, illustrate the versatility of surface in accommodating different molecular arrangements, affecting catalytic performance. We explore diverse adsorption sites influenced by surface topology and electronic properties, revealing a range of adsorption energies from 15.7 to 29.2 kcal/mol. This indicates a complex interplay of molecular forces, significantly impacting catalytic efficiency at distorted sites. Nudged Elastic Band calculations reveal varied activation energies for ethylene insertion, suggesting faster reaction rates at certain sites and highlighting highly favorable dynamics at Corradini type Ti active sites. All these findings offer new directions for enhancing catalyst performances.
